title: The Anti-Blackness of 'Professionalism'
author: Avianne
summary: Under the guise of professionalism, features associated with Blackness—attire, mannerisms, vernacular, and general appearance—are viewed as unfit for an occupational setting and are deeply rooted in anti-Black sentiments.

title: A Right-Wing Brawler Asked a Court to Protect Him From an Antifascist's Tweets
author: Robert Mackey
summary: Adam Kiefer got a restraining order against an antifascist researcher who revealed that he was at the Capitol on Jan. 6. It might have been a costly mistake.

title: Updating The Verge's background policy
author: Nilay Patel
summary: The Verge is updating their public ethics policy to be clearer in their interactions with public relations and corporate communications professionals. They say they're doing this "because big tech companies in particular have hired a dizzying array of communications staff who routinely push the boundaries of acceptable sourcing in an effort to deflect accountability, pass the burden of truth to the media, and generally control the narratives around the companies they work for while being annoying as hell to deal with."

title: Why Misogynists Make Great Informants: How Gender Violence on the Left Enables State Violence in Radical Movements
author: Courtney Desiree Morris
summary: Morris writes about decades of misogyny and abusive behavior within radical leftist organizations, and about how some of the men responsible for it have been infiltrators and informants.

title: Facebook, Citing Societal Concerns, Plans to Shut Down Facial Recognition System
author: Kashmir Hill and Ryan Mac
summary: Saying it wants "to find the right balance" with the technology, the social network will delete the face scan data of more than one billion users.

title: Day 156 and Social Accommodations
author: Julie Fredrickson
summary: Julie Fredrickson writes about the positive difference digital asynchronous communication has on her ability to manage her energy while living with chronic illness. She linked this post in a response to a tweet I retweeted, about if and how people are helping accommodate interviewees with panic attacks or other anxiety issues.

title: It Was Never About Dave
author: Terra Field
summary: Terra Field, a senior software engineer at Netflix and a leader of Netflix's Trans* employee resource group, writes about the recent controversy around Netflix's launch of the Dave Chappelle special, and specifically the reaction to a Twitter thread she created to discuss it.

title: Netflix workers plan a walkout as the fallout over Dave Chappelle continues
author: John Koblin
summary: After the debut of Dave Chappelle's standup special "The Closer" on Netflix, employees are planning a walkout in protest on Wednesday at their Los Angeles office.

relatedReading.title: The Closer (2021 film) § Jokes about the transgender community

title: Observations from my month-long Sabbath
author: Tricia Hersey
summary: Tricia Hersey's learnings from her month-long Sabbath, in which she avoided "all social media, no events, no email, no discussing Nap Ministry work details, no bookings, and no traveling".

title: The last days inside Trailer 83
author: Hannah Dreier
summary: Dreier profiles a family whose home was destroyed in a California wildfire, who spent a year living in a trailer park established by FEMA, then were dropped into homelessness as the park closed. The piece is a part of her examination into why so many people become permanently homeless after losing their homes to wildfire, and highlights ways FEMA is failing people as these disasters only increase in severity and frequency.

relatedReading.title: Federal Emergency Management Agency § California wildfires

title: Don't Let Hybrid Work Set Back Your DEI Efforts
author: Alexandra Samuel and Tara Robertson
summary: Samuel and Robertson outline some things that employers should pay attention to if they are transitioning from being fully remote during the COVID-19 pandemic towards being a hybrid workplace. These include observing who spends more time in the office and at home, ensuring there is equity in who is allowed flexibity in their scheduling of when to be in the office, determining how time in the office affects the promotion process, thinking about how workplace monitoring tools are used, and studying how time at the office (or not) affects employee engagement and retention. I thought it was interesting that the article expressed concern about remote management and monitoring software, while also encouraging employers to use data from things like badge swipes to determine when employees were in the office. It seems to me this data could be used negatively, and possibly pressure employees to come in more than they might otherwise.

title: This Is How Everyday Sexism Could Stop You From Getting That Promotion
author: Jessica Nordell
summary: Researchers created a computer model to illustrate how relatively small instances of gender-based discrimination may build up over time in ways that have marked impacts on women's careers. The author writes about how laws are generally designed to address fairly extreme discriminatory incidents, and don't effectively help with the ongoing, lower-level discrimination that can still have profound effects on a woman's career.

title: The new warrant: how US police mine Google for your location and search history
author: Johana Bhuiyan
summary: Police are increasingly issuing warrants for geofence location data—location data used by companies like Google to return results relevant to their physical location. Bhuiyan describes an incident in which a man's user data was being requested by law enforcement because he had gone on a bike ride with his phone in his pocket, in an area where a burglary had occurred. These are reverse search warrants, where police specify a location and ask for individuals meeting those criteria (rather than a traditional warrant, which applies to an individual). Law enforcement are also increasingly using reverse warrants based on keyword searches, where they ask for lists of individuals who performed specific searches. Some privacy experts and lawyers have argued these broad warrants are similar to general warrants, which were prohibited by the fourth amendment.

title: I Just Don't Want to Be Busy Anymore
author: Elena Salaks
summary: Salaks writes about burnout and some changes she made to her work schedule to ensure she was prioritizing what is important to her. She talks about how this was difficult for her, given her mindset about work, and how she's trying to change that.

title: Women in the Workplace 2021
summary: McKinsey published their annual study of women in the workplace, which analyzes DI&B efforts in corporate America and the experiences of women in the workplace. This year's study found that women are experiencing significantly higher levels of burnout, while also stepping into leadership positions and taking on additional work to support their colleagues and teams. McKinsey found much of DI&B work is done by women, and they are largely going unrecognized for it. The study also found that women of color are continuing to have a worse experience at work, and "although the number of White employees who identify as allies to women of color has increased over the past year, the number taking key allyship actions has not." The study summarizes, "The path forward is clear. Companies need to take bold steps to address burnout. They need to recognize and reward the women leaders who are driving progress. And they need to do the deep cultural work required to create a workplace where all women feel valued."

title: The return of the hacktivists
author: Greg Noone
summary: Hacktivism has experienced a resurgence recently, and particularly in the last few months. Noone researches what's caused the resurgence, how it differs from the "glory days" of Anonymous around 2010, and what ideological and political movements are benefiting from it.

image.alt: A person, photographed from the side, wears a Guy Fawkes mask

title: Spies, Lies, and Stonewalling: What It's Like to Report on Facebook
author: Jacob Silverman
summary: Silverman describes the changing relationship between Facebook and journalists, who once reported largely uncritically on whatever scoops they could muster from the fledgling but popular social media company, and who know have learned to be cautious of the company's word. Facebook has a long history of front-running stories, says Silverman, and aggressively uses off-the-record sourcing to obstruct the reporting process. One journalist describes Facebook's comms team as "willing to lie on record", and journalists and sources are both hypervigilant of the possibility that Facebook could use its own products to expose leakers. Silverman ends by saying, "What Facebook has become is the press's assignment editor, its distribution network, its great antagonist, devourer of its ad revenue, and, through corporate secrecy, a massive block to journalism's core mission of democratic accountability."

title: Without Meaningful Allyship, Hearing People are Doomed to a Never-Ending Cycle of Poor Deaf Awareness
author: Liam O'Dell
summary: O'Dell writes about how it seems that hearing people go through the exact same basic learnings about Deafness over and over again, and that hearing people are not doing enough to work towards learning and allyship with the Deaf community.

title: The USPS' Semi-Secret Internet Surveillance Apparatus
author: Elizabeth Nolan Brown
summary: The Internet Covert Operations Program (iCOP) is a program run by the United States postal service through which they surveil social media networks, ostensibly to "facilitat[e] the identification, disruption, and dismantling of individuals and organizations that use the mail or USPS online tools to facilitate black market Internet trade or other illegal activities".

relatedReading.title: United States Postal Inspection Service § Internet Covert Operations Program

title: Just Say Fat
author: Aubrey Gordon (Your Fat Friend)
summary: Gordon's essay about how she wishes people would just say "fat" rather than using euphemisms, or overly medicalized terms like "obese", or adding caveats like "fat but healthy". She writes about how even when she calls herself fat, people insist she change how she describes her own body, or argue "no, you're not fat!"

title: It's Time to Abolish Nursing Homes
author: Sara Luterman
summary: Luterman argues that we as a society ought to abolish nursing homes. The "efficiency [of nursing homes] comes at the expense of human dignity", she says. She describes their history—how they grew out of the almshouses around the beginning of the 20th century, then private homes filled a void left by the welfare system, and gradually nursing homes became more hospital-like (though often still with poor standards of care). The author says that, although many elderly people want to remain in their homes, many are not aware that in-home care is an option made available to them through Medicaid, and those who are face long waiting lists. The author argues that there needs to be more focus on expanding the amount of in-home care available, more funding towards these services, and work around changing cultural attitudes on things like whether an elderly person with dementia can safely live outside of a nursing facility.

title: Report: Pandemic amped up anti-Semitism, forced it online
author: Laurie Kellman
summary: Although instances of violence against Jews were fewer across many countries in 2020, online antisemitism intensified, stoking fears among some researchers that it will move offline as lockdowns lift. Jews were one of many ethnic and religious groups targeted with conspiracy theories that they had created and/or spread the virus, and antisemitism has been a prominent theme in other conspiracy theories and rhetoric about vaccines, pandemic restrictions, and various organizations working to control the pandemic.

title: Texas 6-week abortion ban takes effect, with high court mum
author: Jessica Gresko, Paul J. Weber, and Mark Sherman
summary: The authors describe the Texas law banning most abortions and authorizing vigilante actions against people who seek abortions, doctors who perform them, and those who "aid and abet" abortions. The law outlaws the vast majority of abortions, as it prevents termination of pregnancies where a heartbeat can be detected, a stage that is often reached before a person even knows they're pregnant. Many reports have been describing this as a "six-week abortion", though this is somewhat misleading, as it is actually four weeks after conception, and two weeks after a missed menstrual cycle. Even a person who takes a pregnancy test the first day after a period is missed would need to obtain an appointment for an abortion, despite all waiting periods, within two weeks. The law took effect at midnight on September 1, 2021, and the Supreme Court did not take action on emergency requests to block the law. This is the first law banning abortions at such an early stage of pregnancy that has been allowed to take effect, even briefly.

title: As Black users complain of censorship, LinkedIn faces a perception problem
author: Steven Melendez
summary: Black LinkedIn users describe problems they've experienced with the platform, including material they post not appearing or being taken down, or getting surprisingly less traffic than expected. LinkedIn has insisted this is not based in systemic bias, but "stem from a mix of content-neutral technical bugs, the popularity among other users of particular posts, and the occasional moderation error". This explanation has been met with (very reasonable) skepticism from Black users.

title: On Workplace Productivity
author: Nicole Forsgren
summary: Forsgren writes about measuring workplace productivity, and the limitations of using common metrics like lines of code or number of commits to do so. She speaks about a "more holistic framework" to measure productivity, which would factor in dimensions like satisfaction, well-being, communication, and collaboration, along with measurements of efficiency or output. She discusses how naive interpretations of GitHub statistics, which show increased time working, more code pushed, and faster merges since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, would suggest a positive outlook on productivity, but that these ignore the enormous amount of burnout and dissatisfaction in the tech industry that point to this being very unsustainable. While I like her idea of a holistic view of productivity, I am generally skeptical of telemetry and automated "measurements" of productivity, which I think do a disservice to workers.

title: Pandemic concerns may prime people to discriminate against Asians and Latinos
author: Amina Khan
summary: A recent study has suggested that "the pandemic has ramped up discrimination against racial and ethnic minority groups — one that may be as widespread as it is difficult to detect". After a surge in incidents of anti-Asian violence related to the pandemic, the researchers investigated whether similar attitudes may be influencing less visible, "everyday" forms of discrimination. Researchers found that survey takers were considerably less likely to respond positively to an Asian or Hispanic person when evaluating roommate candidates when they had been primed to think about the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Apple Cares About Privacy, Unless You Work at Apple
author: Zoe Schiffer
summary: Employees at Apple often link their personal and work accounts for various reasons, including so they can beta test software, and because it is difficult to switch between iCloud accounts. As a result, they have been subjected to major invasions of privacy, including their messages, photos, and other data being exposed. They have been told they are not allowed to wipe any of their devices, potentially exposing extremely personal data including tax and loan information and compromising photographs.

title: The Covid-19 Infodemic — Applying the Epidemiologic Model to Counter Misinformation
author: David Scales, M.D., Ph.D., Jack Gorman, M.D., and Kathleen H. Jamieson, Ph.D.
work: The New England Journal of Medicine
summary: The authors describe an "infodemic" that is occurring in concert with the pandemic, where deceptive material about COVID-19, masks, and vaccines is spreading widely and resulting in those who believe it taking fewer preventative steps against the disease. They discuss engaging pandemic-response playbooks to try to counteract misinformation before it goes viral.

title: Pride Feelings
author: J. Logan Smilges
summary: Smilges talks about how LGBTQ Pride is so often inaccessible to them and their disabled friends for various reasons—"they're too loud, too crowded, and too filled with unwanted or accidental touch, as well as planned without basic accommodations, like ramps, sign language interpreters, and food/drink alternatives for people with specific dietary needs". They talk about the commodification of Pride, and how it is built around serving those who are wealthy, not disabled, gender-conforming, and white. They also talk about how they are rethinking the emotions around disability and queer pride.

title: Burning out and quitting
author: Maya Kaczorowski
summary: Kaczorowski describes her recent experience with burnout, and how it's different from her experiences with the phenomenon before the pandemic began. She gives advice on how to treat people who are experiencing burnout, and she also talks about how she believes that there will be a massive amount of burnout (or people acting on current burnout) in the near future as people move past the uncertainty of the earlier portions of the pandemic.

title: Disability is More Than Just Inspiration or Trauma. When Will Media Cover it Authentically?
author: Shona Louise
summary: Louise writes about how the media prefers to show disability in the form of "inspiration porn" or stories of traumatic events, but refuses to cover serious issues affecting disabled people. She laments the lack of openly disabled journalists, which she says contributes to the continuing narrative of "person disabled by shocking and traumatic event, hates being disabled, 'overcomes' their disability".

title: The Hotel Giraffe
author: Michael Lopp
summary: Rands writes about stress, things he does to combat stress, and leading indicators of when "it's about to hit the fan" in terms of stress. He also talks about how he checks in with his team on their stress levels.

title: 'Best for Diversity' lists actively hinder progress. Stop submitting to them.
author: Aubrey Blanche
summary: Blanche argues that 'Best Workplaces for Diversity' and similar lists allow companies to give the impression that they are positive workplaces for underrepresented minorities when they may not be, while diverting money and time from programs that could actually change organizations in positive ways. I particularly like her argument that the lists drive competition between companies in this area, rather than collaboration—companies could be working together to raise the overall bar for how URMs are treated in the industry, rather than competing to be the "best". Blanche clarifies that she does believe in benchmarking for DI&B in order for companies to understand if what they're doing is effective, but that these benchmarks need to incentivize effectiveness in making positive change rather than just good PR or pressuring employees to respond positively to surveys that feed these lists.

title: The Delta Variant Is Sending More Children to the Hospital. Are They Sicker, Too?
author: Emily Anthes
summary: Children have been particularly affected by the COVID-19 Delta variant, and doctors are questioning whether the variant could be particularly dangerous in younger people. Scientists have said there is insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about whether the Delta variant causes more severe illness in children than other variants. In the UK, where there was a surge in Delta variant cases before the one in the US, there was no clear evidence that children were at particular risk for serious illness from this variant.

image.alt: A twelve-year-old wearing a mask sits on some steps, with a younger child and an older adult standing behind her in a door way

relatedReading.title: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on children

title: Editorial: MBTA shows bad side of remote working
summary: An executive working remotely for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority was recently discovered to have spent nine months "double-dipping" by working simultaneously for the Denver transit agency. Editorial staff at the Boston Herald point to this as an example of the "bad side of remote working" that results from employers who "[fail] to police remote workers": "This is what's wrong with remote work. Some will look to cut corners." The authors argue that the MBTA owes it to taxpayers and riders to monitor their employees.

image.alt: Orange line MBTA trains sit on the tracks at a station

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Mandates Split Corporate America
author: Chip Cutter, Sarah Nassauer and Bob Tita
summary: More than a third of eligible adult Americans haven't gotten a COVID-19 vaccine, and employers are weighing approaches to requiring or encouraging vaccination among their workforce. Some are requiring vaccines (either for all staff, or for new hires only), some have offered various incentives or tried to educate their employees about the vaccine, and some have not made any statements on the matter.

image.alt: Masked employees at Disneyland standing in a line wave at guests

title: Looking for COVID-19 'Miracle Drugs'? We Already Have Them. They're Called Vaccines
author: Claire Berlinski and Yuri Deigin
summary: An article from Quillette, a generally libertarian- and right-leaning publication, offers an interesting and admirable attempt to convince its readers to be wary of COVID-19 misinformation, and to get vaccinated against COVID-19. Berlinski and Deigin describe Bret Weinstein's statements about COVID-19, which they say evolved from "entertaining theories that might not be right but could do no harm, to theories that cannot be right and are sure to do harm". They criticize Weinstein's claims that ivermectin is a COVID-19 "miracle drug" (which they say is inaccurate but also relatively harmless, as ivermectin has few side effects), as well as his statements that the approved COVID-19 vaccines are so unsafe that people are dying from them en masse (statements they describe as "deadly"). The article offers a perspective that is both deeply libertarian, and also often missing from publications further to the right: "It is Weinstein's right under the First Amendment to say all of this. But let's not confuse a right to say something with something being right to say." It also debunks some of the claims that Weinstein has made on his podcast (for example, "The impression listeners might get from Weinstein's podcast is that children are at no risk from this disease. This is false."), and details the actual risks of COVID-19 vaccines and the scale at which side effects such as blood clots have been observed. The article concludes: "To put things simply: We have proof that ivermectin is terrific for river blindness and head lice. But if you're taking it to prevent COVID-19 because you heard it was '99 percent effective' on a podcast—while forgoing an mRNA vaccine, because you think that's too dangerous—you've been misled, and you're endangering yourself, your family, your community, and your country. No one disputes Bret Weinstein's right to embrace the theory that ivermectin is a miracle drug, or to regale his listeners with vaccine horror stories and conspiracy theories. But the rest of us reserve the right to be appalled by his judgment and ethics."

title: The Kick-Ass Shit That Women In The Game Industry Don't Get Enough Credit For
author: Ari Notis and Patricia Hernandez
summary: After all the coverage of the lawsuit against Activision Blizzard and the women who have been victimized at that company, Notis and Hernandez spotlight some of the very impressive work women in the games industry have done.

image.alt: Illustration of Ana from Overwatch

title: 'You're the Problem': When They Spoke Up About Misconduct, They Were Offered Mental Health Services
author: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Ruchika Tulshyan
summary: Employees at Google have described a pattern at the company where employees reporting issues like harassment and discrimination were directed to employee assistance programs (EAPs) for mental health counselling in lieu of proper investigations into the issues. They also describe scenarios where the company subpoenaed records from these counselling sessions to use against them in litigation. Some employees describe how this made them feel that the problem was with them, not with the employee(s) acting in harassing or discriminatory ways.

image.alt: A digital collage of eyes and mouths, superimposed over an illustration of a computer and a chat bubble.

title: Department of Fair Employment and Housing v. Activision Blizzard, Inc.
summary: The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing (DFEH) has filed a lawsuit against Activision Blizzard, the games company best known for games like World of Warcraft and Overwatch. The lawsuit alleges systemic underrepresentation, underpayment, and underpromotion of women and people of color across the company, as well as a "frat boy" culture of harassment and discrimination in which "women are subjected to 'cube crawls' in which male employees drink copious amounts of alcohol as they 'crawl' their way through various cubicles in the office and often engage in inappropriate behavior toward female employees. Male employees proudly come into work hungover, play video games for long periods of time during work while delegating their responsibilities to female employees, engage in banter about their sexual encounters, talk openly about female bodies, and joke about rape." The lawsuit alleges that HR was complicit in these issues, which pervaded the company up to and including at the executive level.

relatedReading.title: California Department of Fair Employment and Housing v. Activision Blizzard

title: Give Everybody the Month of August Off
author: Miles Kampf-Lassin
summary: Kampf-Lassin compares mandated vacation time policies in European countries to the norms in the United States, explaining that in many European countries it is standard to take several weeks or even the entire month of August off. He describes the legislation requiring several weeks of paid vacation for all employees, and compares it to standards in US companies, where it can take 20 years before someone accrues even 20 days of paid leave in a year. He also describes research that has found that taking substantial vacation time increases productivity and economic output.

image.alt: People swimming silhouetted under a sunset

relatedReading.title: List of minimum annual leave by country

title: ACT UP: A History of AIDS/HIV Activism
author: Sarah Schulman, interviewed by Sam Sanders
summary: Sarah Schulman, a rank-and-file member of ACT UP New York since the 1980s, codirects the ACT UP Oral History Project, and wrote a book chronicling the group's activism. She speaks about the history of AIDS/HIV, activism, and ACT UP's role in it. She talks about what worked well for that movement, as well as its shortcomings, and the learnings that contemporary activist movements can take from it.

title: Female Twitch Streamers Spend Their Lives Online. Predators Are Watching.
author: Jesselyn Cook
summary: Women who stream on Twitch face enormous amounts of harassment, particularly sexual harassment, enduring an "environment where extreme harassment, rape and death threats, blackmailing, stalking and worse have become regular workplace hazards." Dedicated subreddits have been created to share unintentionally revealing screengrabs and digitally-created porn of these women, and their attempts to have the subreddits and similarly abusive channels removed have largely been futile. One streamer pays $2,500 a month for a firm to help remove sexualized images of her from the internet, and even then platforms usually only remove it when claims are filed based on copyright rather than on sexual harassment grounds. Some viewers have developed parasocial relationships with the female streamers, and some streamers have been targeted with violent threats and both online and in-person stalking.

image.alt: Collage of two images; one on the left shows a closeup of the face of streamer SweetAnita looking downwards; the one on the right shows a red-filtered image of her looking at a cell phone in her hand.

title: Opinion: This San Francisco-based website is a favorite of neo-Nazis to spread their hatred
author: Steven Stalinsky
summary: The Internet Archive, a massive online library, has been used by neo-Nazis, antisemites, and other white supremacist and racist groups to host propoganda and incitement. Stalinsky writes about how the organization has done little to prevent usage by extremist and terrorist groups, even after years of knowing of their usage of the site, and claims that it is not responsible for the content shared using its service.

title: Company That Aims to Solve the 'Crisis of Toxicity Online' Makes Money From the Daily Caller and Ben Shapiro
author: Shoshana Wodinsky
summary: A company that claims to provide a more socially conscious advertising platform to companies is displaying ads on sites like the Daily Caller and those run by Ben Shapiro. More generally, Wodinsky talks about the motivations behind companies removing ads from far-right sites.

image.alt: A man wearing an American flag print gater covering most of his face holds a riot shield while standing in a crowd of other men.

title: Making the Subway Safer With Fewer Police
author: Hadriana Lowenkron
summary: A recent report from a NYC transit think tank argues that heavy police presence on public transit has exacerbated issues of racism in policing, and is not the best way to promote public safety. The report argues that police should deprioritize enforcing low-level offenses like fare evasion and public sleeping, and increase unarmed personnel to offer aid for those who are unhoused or experiencing mental health issues. According to the report, 90% of people arrested for fare-related offenses by the NYPD from October 2017 to June 2019 were people of color. Furthermore, officers in the NYPD testified they were told to focus on Black and brown fare evaders, and ignore those who were white or Asian.

image.alt: Police officers walk through the Union Square subway station

title: I'm Not a Reporter. But I'm Verified as One on Twitter
author: Albert Fox Cahn
summary: Cahn explains Twitter's new criteria for verifying accounts, and how it disadvantages activists (particularly of color). According to Cahn, it is much easier to be verified as a journalist, since they only need to submit three recent bylines; activists must satisfy a slew of requirements such as being in the top 0.05% of users in a region, or starting a major hashtag. According to anti-racist economist Kim Crayton, "that blue check automatically means that what you have to say is of value, and without it, particularly if you're on the front lines, particularly if you're a Black woman, you're questioned."

image.alt: A Black person holding a sign above their head with a checkmark on it peeks out of a hole in the ground

title: Exclusive extract: how Facebook's engineers spied on women
author: Sheera Frenkel and Cecilia Kang
summary: Audits at Facebook showed that more than fifty employees misused their access to user data for personal reasons, and that many of the incidents involved male employees looking up women they were interested in romantically. One employee was able to use his access to track down a woman who had rented a new hotel room after a fight, and another was able to show up at a park where a prospective date was socializing with friends. Because of few security measures and auditing, they are unable to know the full scope of data that was improperly accessed in this way.

image.alt: Hands typing on a keyboard, overlaid with a sillhouette of a woman

title: Five ways to include d/Deaf users in your designs
author: Rachele DiTullio
summary: DiTullio gives a list of five ways to improve online experiences for d/Deaf users: including visual indicators of audio cues, providing text equivalents of audio content, providing sign language, writing with d/Deaf people in mind, and testing designs with d/Deaf people.

title: The Overlooked Children Working in America's Tobacco Fields
author: Ariel Ramchandani
summary: Children as young as ten years old are working in American fields for large companies, picking cash crops including tobacco and produce. Although working in tobacco fields holds particular dangers with the exposure to nicotine (which is neurotoxic), all farm labor is particularly dangerous to children due to pesticide exposure, high physical demands, usage of dangerous machinery and tools, exposure to extreme weather, and many other reasons. The issue is in part due to poor regulations, but even existing regulations that would prevent child labor are largely unenforced and ineffective.

image.alt: An illustration of a child holding a large leafy plant over their head, looking out over a field.

relatedReading.title: Child labor laws in the United States

title: Understand the TikTok strike.
author: Nicole Cardoza
summary: Black TikTok creators are on strike over cultural appropriation and not being given credit for their content (or having credit stolen) on the TikTok app. White creators have been miscredited as creators of viral TikTok trends, and have benefited from sponsorships and media recognition that belongs to Black creators.

title: Apple isn't backing down from its hybrid work model, according to internal note
author: Zoe Schiffer
summary: Apple recently announced that it will require employees to return to the office on three days a week. After employees wrote to leadership asking them to reconsider, saying that "without the inclusivity that flexibility brings, many of us feel we have to choose between either a combination of our families, our well-being, and being empowered to do our best work, or being a part of Apple", Apple denied the request.

image.alt: An illustration of the Apple logo on a black background, surrounded by red shapes.

title: The Diversity and Inclusion Industry Has Lost Its Way
author: Kim Tran
summary: Kim Tran writes that "DEI is a corporate litigation shield meant to protect those in power from the people over whom they wield it." She asks, "What would it mean to radically reimagine DEI? To recast it not as a mere shadow, but a reflection of the social protest from which it formed?" She suggests that "DEI needs to shed its bourgeois skin", and that individuals employed in DEI ought to join rank-and-file workers engaging in actions like the Wayfair walkouts and the attempts to unionize at Amazon warehouses.

image.alt: A digital illustration of raised fists collaged with people on a staircase

title: Trolls use a little-known Twitter feature to swarm others with abuse, and their targets say Twitter hasn't done much to stop it
author: Lauren Feiner
summary: After talking to someone on Twitter about how they had experienced the usage of Twitter's "lists" feature in harassment campaigns targeting them, I found this CNBC article discussing this longterm issue with the platform. There is no way to remove oneself from a Twitter list, prevent yourself from being added to lists, or otherwise deter their usage as a tool to amplify harassment campaigns often targeted a gender or racial minorities.

image.alt: Sillhouttes of people looking at cell phones, overlaid on a Twitter blue background with the Twitter logo

title: Who's left out when tech embraces Juneteenth?
author: Mathew Katz
summary: Katz wrote last year about tech companies giving employees the day off for Juneteenth. He points out that there are many days, such as Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, where white collar workers get the day off but many others don't, and that Juneteenth risks becoming one of these holidays. He points out how last year, when Uber gave its largely white corporate employees the day off, its more racially diverse workforce of drivers didn't get a paid holiday. He concludes by saying that "Unless Congress acts to make Juneteenth a federal holiday -- and let me be clear, they should -- largely-white tech companies run the risk of creating yet another two-tiered American holiday that leaves many people of color behind." I think he is overly optimistic to think that Juneteenth becoming a federal holiday, as it just has, will be enough to prevent this split.

title: Much More Than A Holiday: How Tech Companies Should Commemorate Juneteenth
author: Brenda D. Wilkerson
summary: Wilkerson outlines how tech companies can commemorate Juneteenth in a meaningful way. Her list includes making a 5- to 10-year plan to make meaningful actions, being prepared to answer for past missteps, continuously evaluating and scoring how they are doing on DEI initiatives, creating a buddy system among other leaders, and looking beyond their company and employees.

title: Attorneys for woman in Winston Smith's car say she did not see him with a gun
author: Maya Rao and Alex Chhith
summary: On June 3, law enforcement killed Winston Boogie Smith, a 32-year-old Black man, after alleging he drew a gun on them while they were attempting to arrest him on a warrant. This description of events has been contradicted by a woman who was in the car with him, who said she had never seen a gun on Smith or in his car. The incident is complicated by the fact that the warrant was served by U.S. Marshals assisted by local law enforcement, who were not allowed to use body cameras or dashcams while making the arrest, a policy which has been changed in the aftermath of Smith's death.

image.alt: Winston Boogie Smith

title: Two Marin schools forced to integrate after years of segregation and battles for funding
author: Jill Tucker and Emma Talley
summary: The authors underscore how racial segregation in schools is not a phenomenon of the past, giving the example of two schools in Marin, a county which, despite its reputation as a bastion of liberal politics, is the most segregated county in the Bay Area. Until being forced to integration, two schools in the same zip code were massively different in terms of the racial breakdown of their students, the funding allocated per student, and educational outcomes.

image.alt: A student and her mother stand outside Bayside Martin Luther King Jr. Academy, which before the desegregation had only 8% white students

relatedReading.title: Racial segregation in the United States § Contemporary segregation

title: Airbnb Is Spending Millions of Dollars to Make Nightmares Go Away
author: Olivia Carville
summary: Airbnb has spent tens of millions of dollars annually on payouts to victims of crimes, some extremely serious, that have occurred in Airbnbs. Sometimes perpetrated by hosts, sometimes by guests, Carville questions how much Airbnb's trust and safety team's generous payouts are intended to benefit victims rather than used as a way to avoid bad PR, which could affect the service's popularity and lead to stricter regulations on a minimally-regulated service. Some members of the team have said they were asked to prioritize higher-profile but less serious incidents (such as those involving reality TV stars or influencers). Settlements which prevent victims of crimes from blaming or suing the company, and language in the platform's terms of service, have also allowed Airbnb to skirt lawsuits, and limited courts' ability to establish the extent to which hosts for Airbnb and similar services could hbe held liable for crimes that are committed in their properties.

image.alt: Cover of Bloomberg Businessweek featuring this story. The cover features the headline, and a photograph of light shining underneath a door, where shadows show a person is standing directly behind it.

title: Pink Dot 12: Bryan Choong's Story
summary: Bryan Choong tells his story about being gay in Singapore, and while serving in the country's armed forces. He explains why he is one of the people who has challenged the constitutionality of Section 377A, a law criminalizing sex between consenting adult men.

title: Analyze corporate commitments to racial equity.
author: Nicole Cardoza
summary: During the mid-2020 racial reckoning in the United States, companies pledged a total of $50 billion to initiatives related to racial equity. However, only $250 million has actually been spent or committed to such projects. Furthermore, while amounts committed by some companies sound significant, they often are dwarfed in comparison to the company's total profits. There is considerable, and reasonable, skepticism around the actual progress that's being made by various companies (many in the tech industry) who made commitments related to racial equity. Cardoza discusses where companies have fallen short in these areas and speaks to some employees who have had poor experiences with lip service towards racial justice at their companies. Much of the actual work has fallen on individuals, often members of underrepresented groups themselves.

title: Report: Asian American Women Twice as Likely to Be Targets of Anti-Asian Hate
summary: A joint study by the National Asian Pacific American Women's Forum (NAPAWF) and Stop AAPI Hate found that Asian American women are twice as likely as Asian American men to self-report being targeted in anti-Asian hate incidents. The study also found that half of AAPI women experienced a specific incident of anti-Asian racism in the last two years. Although thhe COVID-19 Hate Crimes Act provides some positive investments in community-centered solutions to anti-Asian hate, many Asian American and LGBTQ groups oppose it due to its mostly carceral solutions.

image.alt: Photograph of the NYC public art installation "I Still Believe in Our City" featuring artwork by Amanda Phingbodhipakkiya. Three framed images hang on a wall with illustrations of AAPI individuals, and read "I did not make you sick", "This is our home too", and "I am not your scapegoat".

relatedReading.title: Xenophobia and racism related to the COVID-19 pandemic § United States

title: The AIDS Memorial Quilt
author: Cleve Jones and the National AIDS Memorial project
summary: Cleve Jones, the activist who came up with the idea of the AIDS memorial quilt, describes the painful history of the AIDS crisis that began in the 1980s, and what led him to begin the quilt project both to commemorate those who died from AIDS, but also force people to pay attention.

title: Nurses in Massachusetts Are Striking for Their Patients
author: Katie Murphy, interviewed by Alexandra Bruns-Smith and Matthew Erlich
summary: Worcester nurses at Saint Vincent Hospital have been striking since March 8, over "safe staffing"—that is, ensuring there are a proper number of nurses to treat patients. The head of the nurse's union says that the fight against the strike by the company that owns the hospital is about power; she says that the amount the hospital has spent on police and security related to the strike could easily fund the extra staffing the strikers are demanding. The hospital has also recently threatened to permanently replace the nurses who are striking, which she describes as a scare tactic, because the hospital has been unable to fill positions since before the strike.

image.alt: Nurses strike outside Saint Vincent Hospital. Some hold signs that say "Shame on Tenet CEO Carolyn Jackson", and some hold signs that say "St. Vincent Hospital Safe Staffing Now"

title: The Awkward Playdate Negotiations When Your Kids Aren't Vaccinated Yet
author: Alina Dizik
summary: Although more and more adults are becoming fully vaccinated each day, there is still no vaccine available for children under 12. While they are less susceptible to serious illness from COVID-19, they are still at risk for the illness. Some parents are beginning to relax the precautions they were taking with their children, allowing large unmasked group get-togethers, whereas others are continuing to be more cautious. Parents are having to navigate discussing COVID safety with parents who are more ambivalent, and also figure out how to balance safety with potentially introducing difficulties into their childrens' friendships. One parent said of their willingness to relax a previously-enforced precaution: "You don't want to be the first parent and you don't want to be last."

image.alt: A group of unmasked children play on a large swing.

title: Promote agricultural education
author: Tiffany Onyejiaka
summary: Onyejiaka advocates for including agricultural education in students' curriculums, both to teach students how to grow vegetables and other crops, but also to teach them about histories of inequality in access to food (particularly produce) by race and income.

title: The Invisible "THEY"
author: Jules Rey
summary: Brazil continues to be an extremely hostile country towards trans people, as reflected in healthcare, politics, and society in general. However, there is some positive change happening: thirty trans candidates were elected in the most recent election, and a judge recently recognized peoples' rights to have their gender acknowledged as neutral (in the specific case, allowing a name and gender change on official documents).

image.alt: Brazilians celebrating during one of São Paulo's pride parades

title: Poor in Tech
author: Meg Elison
summary: Elison lists a number of examples of times she knew she was the only person at her tech startup, and times when she felt alienated by her wealthy colleagues who made assumptions that everyone they worked with was like them.

title: Words Matter: Alternatives for Charged Terminology in the Computing Profession
summary: ACM provides a list of common technological terms they suggest avoiding, as they can be exclusionary or offensive. They also provide a list of alternatives. I thought this was very useful, as I recently found myself struggling to come up with a synonym for "blacklist" (ACM suggests "blocklist"). They also have a form at the bottom to allow people to submit more items to the (fairly short) list. I'll be curious to see what's added over time.

title: The Masks Are (Finally) Coming Off
author: Michael Brendan Dougherty
summary: Dougherty writes about mask mandates as they begin to lift, taking the view that some of them (masks outdoors, masking children in schools) they have been unjustified for a long time.

image.alt: Two unmasked people walk under signs urging mask-wearing and social distancing during Spring Break in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., March 24, 2021.

title: How The Politics Of White Liberals And White Conservatives Are Shaped By Whiteness
author: Hakeem Jefferson and Koji Takahashi
summary: The authors explore how white Americans across the political spectrum view their whiteness, and how they react to others' perceptions of their whiteness. They discuss the ways people react to things like the association between whiteness and privilege.

image.alt: Two pixelated photos, one of a white man and one of a white woman, with purple and orange filters

title: Workism Is Making Americans Miserable
author: Derek Thompson
summary:
"Workism" is when work is central to one's identity and defines their life's purpose; it is also the belief that policies to promote human welfare must always promote more work. Workism is common in wealthy men, but people across all classes and genders are finding themselves immersed in a culture that centers around work.
I found one portion of this article questionable: "95 percent of teens said 'having a job or career they enjoy' would be 'extremely or very important' to them as an adult. This ranked higher than any other priority, including 'helping other people who are in need' (81 percent) or getting married (47 percent). Finding meaning at work beats family and kindness as the top ambition of today's young people." This seems an odd conclusion to draw, and it seems odd to include it in an article about workism at all. I think most people who do not define themselves around their work still wish to have a job they enjoy, and it also seems odd to infer that a teenager not prioritizing marriage highly means they don't highly value family in general.

image.alt: Stock photo of a person with their hands clasped over their head

title: Politicizing Critical Race Theory Is Meant to Keep Public Education Oppressive, Biased and Basic
author: Tanesha Peeples
summary: Peeples criticizes legislators and those lobbying for bills that would ban the teaching of critical race theory in public schools. She compares the "parent advocacy groups" (reported upon by the St. Louis Post-Dispatch) who allege that school districts are "pushing social justice and equity ideals that amount to a Marxist takeover of schools that paints white students as oppressors and Black students as victims" to the women in the KKK who harassed and threatened Black school administrators for diversifying curriculum and school leadership.

image.alt: A Black teenager holds a sign that reads 'Stop politicizing education'. In black and white next to her are other students with their heads down on desks.

title: Reaching 'Herd Immunity' Is Unlikely in the U.S., Experts Now Believe
author: Apoorva Mandavilli
summary: Herd immunity, once believed to be an achievable goal that would mark the end of the pandemic and a return to normalcy, is no longer something most scientists believe to be possible. This is due to a combination of increased thresholds of vaccination that would be require to achieve such immunity (due to the emergence of more contagious variants of the virus), and hesitancy among the general population to be vaccinated. Mandavilli discusses how herd immunity would need to be achieved at all levels—at the local, city level as well as on a state-, country-, and worldwide level, before it would be truly effective. She discusses what a future without herd immunity may look like.

image.alt: A healthcare professional gives a vaccine in a large stadium type venue.

title: 'We are witnessing a crime against humanity': Arundhati Roy on India's Covid catastrophe
author: Arundhati Roy
summary: Roy describes the extent of the COVID-19 crisis currently affecting India, as well as the fact that the estimates are likely to be far lower than reality. He also describes what could graciously be called failures in leadership and government, but which he believes would more accurately be called crimes against humanity, that have resulted in this crisis.

image.alt: People stand outside near a row of oxygen canisters.

title: What really happened at Basecamp
author: Casey Newton
summary: Newton explains how a list of "funny" customer names led to choice by Basecamp leadership to ban "societal and political discussions" at work, which led to a third of their workforce leaving the company. The impetus for the blog post, which also announced the end of "paternalistic benefits", committees, and 360 reviews, was previously unknown.

image.alt: Basecamp logo

title: When communities try to hold police accountable, law enforcement fights back
author: Nicole Dungca and Jenn Abelson

image.alt: Sharpied dates on a wall indicate police killings. The writing reads: "5/16/19 (NMSP); 7/3/19 (APD); 3/3/20 (BCSO); 6/7/18 (RRPD)"

summary: The Washington Post investigated civilian review boards of police departments, finding that they were ineffectual and often powerless to hold police officers and departments accountable. For example, in Louisville, where Breonna Taylor was murdered in March of 2020, the Citizens Commission on Police Accountability couldn't open an investigation or take citizen complaints; it was limited to reviewing alread-closed internal affairs investigations. Even upon such a review, they could not recommend disclipline; only opine on whether the investigation was sufficient and recommend policy or training changes. In Minneapolis, the officer who murdered George Floyd had already been the subject of 22 misconduct complaints from 2003–2015, and the civilian reviewers handled twelve, but Chauvin remained an officer and did not change his conduct in any way that prevented him from killing Floyd. Some locations massively limit the power of such review committees, and some bar them outright. In some places where oversight committees can recommend disciplinary action for officers, the final decision lies with the police chiefs. Police unions, individuals in law enforcement, and politicians have also tried to block laws calling for more oversight, and pressure those in oversight roles.

title: COVID-19, Resource Colonialism & Indigenous Resistance
author: Klee Benally
summary: While some attention has been paid to the high incidence of COVID-19 among Indigenous people, Benally says it is being misattributed and misportrayed in dehumanizing, colonialist ways. Benally describes the additional factors that are not being widely acknowledged, such as methane pollution of Diné lands contributing to lung weakness and thus making people more susceptible to the virus. He gives a detailed history of mining operations in the area, as well as efforts by Diné environmental groups to resist them, and interference by politicians on the Navajo Nation. He also describes the status of Diné Bikéyah as a food desert, and explains that this was only a result of colonialist invasion and continued policies that negatively impact access to food and farming. Benally criticizes white saviors—"Self-appointed allies, ranging in political spectrum from anarchists to Christian missionaries"—who have attempted to treat the Diné as a charity project, and to maintain control over them. He also describes the mutual aid and direct action that has been happening within Diné Bikéyah.

image.alt: Graphic with the title and author of the post, with the biohazard symbol and a person wearing a gas mask

relatedReading.title: COVID-19 pandemic in the Navajo Nation

title: We Are Fighting for a World Where Ma'Khia Bryant Would Have Lived
author: Amna A. Akbar and Treva B. Lindsey
summary: The authors explain how the killing of Ma'Khia Bryant was one in a long string of killings by police in the United States, but also in Columbus, Ohio specifically. They discuss how Bryant was not a "perfect victim" and how that has led some people to dismiss her killing as justified. "Ma'Khia Bryant isn't a mythical, perfect victim, nor does she need to be for us to unequivocally affirm that her death was unnecessary. She's someone who forces us to contend with our values and challenge our continued investment in a system of policing that sees killing a Black girl with a knife as the only reasonable and effective response. The question we need to ask is not whether Reardon had the legal right to kill her, but rather: Didn't Ma'Khia and the other people involved in the altercation deserve to live?"

image.alt: Ohio State students hold a sit in. Many have signs reading things like "Say Their Names" and "Stop Killing Us"

title: Our Black Maternal Health Crisis Is a Racial Justice Issue That Demands Bold Solutions
author: U.S. Representative Ayanna Pressley and Dr. Myechia Minter Jordan
summary: Pressley and Dr. Jordan describe disparities in maternal healthcare as a result of racism and inequitable access, and explain how maternal healthcare is a racial justice issue that requires substantive solutions. They suggest expanding Medicaid to cover more maternity-related issues and a longer period of time. It explains the Healthy MOMMIES Act, introduced by Pressley and colleagues. The piece also describes the importance of oral health to overall health, which is an interesting topic that I had not considered specifically in relation to maternal healthcare.

image.alt: A pregnant Black couple, with only their midsections visible. One has their hands on the pregnant person's stomach.

relatedReading.title: Black maternal mortality in the United States

title: The Daunte Wright Shooting: What We Know So Far
author: Dingane Xaba, Niko Georgiades, Unicorn Riot
summary: The authors give an overview of the events leading up to and surrounding the police killing of Daunte Wright, as well as ensuing protests. They describe ongoing issues with police response to protests in Minneapolis, including violence against protesters, targeting of press, and holding detained individuals on suspicion of riot charges, likely related only to possession of gas masks.

image.alt: Daunte Wright holding his child at their first birthday party

title: Meet the introverts who are dreading a return to normal
author: Roxanne Roberts

image.alt: Illustration of two people indoors reading books, while people walk around outside

summary: Roberts discusses introverts who are apprehensive about "returning to normal" after widespread vaccination and easing of COVID-19 restrictions. I didn't agree with a lot of it—particularly the comparison between returning to post-COVID normalcy and returning to prison—though I did find the statement by the psychoogist they interviewed to be thought-provoking: "The pandemic is what psychologist Susan Krauss Whitbourne calls a 'time of measurement' effect — the rare historical event so profound that it alters perceptions and personalities. 'So psychology won't be the same for a number of years now, just as after World War I and World War II.'" I also appreciated the mention of the dissonance between the happiness 2020 has brought some of us, and the horror of the pandemic.

title: How to provide anti-racist mental health care
author: Jude Mary Cénat
summary: Cénat describes the impact of individual, institutional, and systemic racism on the health of those it affects. The article describes racism within the medical and psychiatric fields, and urges practicioners to take an anti-racist approach in their treatment. The article provides a long list of guidelines to provide anti-racist mental health care, which includes advice for practioners to increase their awareness of racism and use culturally-appropriate assessments.

title: Meet the gun-toting 'Tenacious Unicorns' in rural Colorado
author: Eric Siegel
summary: I stumbled across the Tenacious Unicorn Ranch on Twitter in March, when they were asking for donations to fund protective measures (fencing, floodlights, etc.) against local militia that were threatening the people who live there. It's worth a follow for the alpaca (and dog and other livestock) photos alone, but it's also such a cool idea, and I love their futuristic "earthship" building. I sought out an article to learn more about the group and found this profile by a Colorado journalist. Immediately drawn in by the photographs and the quote about geodesic domes ("They are weird but useful, which is the essence of queer."), I loved reading about how they made a home for themselves even in an area that had become a "cauldron of right-wing conservatism" and galvanized other progressives. This was published before the heightened harassment by militias and other members of the right-wing, but discusses many of the challenges they've faced with local groups who challenge their right to live and farm in the area. It also informed me about Mission: Wolf, another countercultural community in the area that is focused on creating a wolf sanctuary, which I am interested to learn about.

title: A feminist internet would be better for everyone
author: Charlotte Jee
summary: Jee envisions a version of the Internet that was built with the intention of being safe for women, rather than with halfhearted protections added on later. She talks about ways this would be accomplished, including giving more control to users, reducing the online economy's reliance on advertising and data collection and sale, and using strict privacy settings by default. She also talks about how tech companies always need to consider how their products could be misused.

title: Doctor: This unethical Arkansas law should horrify all in medical profession
author: Jack Turban
summary: The so-called Medical Ethics and Diversity Act introduced in Arkansas allows healthcare workers to deny non-emergency healthcare to individuals based on their personal moral objections. Turban writes that this contradicts health care providers' professional responsibilities, and that the "non-emergency" provision does not prevent this from threatening individuals' lives.

title: It's not 'them' — it's us!
author: Betsy Leondar-Wright
summary:
This is an excellent article that a friend who read this page recommended to me, and I similarly recommend it to anyone else reading this. Leondar-Wright discusses how progressive-middle-class activists (PMCs) often do not see characteristics of our own that can be alienating to members of the working class, and how our alternative values can "confuse us about who's the enemy" and "may [cause us to] take a superior attitude that working-class people will correctly read as classism". She also distinguishes between "essential weirdness" (for example, gay people may seem weird to a particular group, but it is essential for organizations to support them being out) and personal differences that are very important to an individual and must be respected (a recovering alcoholic not drinking even if it seems weird in a particular space), from personal choices that ought not to be imposed on others (a vegan planning an all-vegan menu at a conference not devoted to veganism) and "inessential weirdness" (a group of activists suggesting everyone howl like wolves during a coffee break).
"So here's a shorthand version of my point: if you want to build cross-class alliances, don't howl. If howling is important to you, go off on a howling retreat with other howlers; don't do it in coalition spaces. Blend in if there's not a strong reason not to. Truly, you can be your authentic self without indulging your impulses to howl." The article ends with a list of five guidelines for PMC activists to follow to maximize the effectiveness of their work, and to help build cross-class alliances.

title: Advocate for gun control laws
author: Tracey Onyenacho
summary: Onyenacho outlines some of the existing gun control legislation in place, including background checks and mandatory waiting periods. They also explain that if a background check is not completed in time (three days), a person may purchase a firearm—basically, an objection must be raised in that three-day period, and regardless of whether it's because no concern was discovered or because the FBI didn't have time to run the check, a person may proceed with the purchase. She outlines some proposed changes to gun control legislation, including extending the time period for background checks to be run, and requiring private gun sellers to run background checks (a decision which is currently up to the states). I was shocked at how many people own guns—they cite the Pew Research Center's 2017 report to show that 48% of white men own a firearm, as do 24% of white women. 24% of non-white men and 16% of non-white women do as well. I would be curious to know how those statistics have changed, particularly given reports of increased gun purchasing in the past year or two. I looked around for more recent data but it understandably seems to lag a bit—a lot of more recent sources were citing the same 2017 Pew study. At the top of the article, the author provides a list of actions to take to support gun control legislation.

title: An urban farm embarks on its first season, determined to serve its community
author: Jocelyn Ruggiero
summary: Ruggiero profiles the Bello family's Agric Organics Urban Farm in Wilbraham, which they created after observing the severity of the food desert in Springfield, which has the second-lowest per-capita income in Massachusetts. They will allow people to participate in a CSA program using SNAP cards, sell produce for affordable prices, and donate at least 10% of their vegetables.

title: The Mobile Performance Inequality Gap, 2021
author: Alex Russell
summary: Russell discusses the current baseline for mobile device performance, and how frontend developers are creating poor experiences for many users by building single page applications and other web experiences that are much heavier than what these devices (and networks) can support. "When we construct a digital world to the limits of the best devices, the worse an experience we build, on average, for those who cannot afford iPhones or $800 Samsung flagships."

title: Experts Say the 'New Normal' in 2025 Will Be Far More Tech-Driven, Presenting More Big Challenges
author: Janna Anderson, Lee Rainie, and Emily A. Vogels
summary: Canvassing by the Pew Research Center summarizes a sample of expert opinions on how life will be in 2025. Notably more respondents (47%) believed that life will be "mostly worse" for people in 2025 than before the pandemic than believed would be "mostly better" (39%), though not when combined with the number who said it will be roughly the same (14%). Concerns about 2025 included worsening economic inequality, increasing power of Big Tech, and the continuing spread of misinformation. Positive predictions for 2025 included reforms relating to racial and social justice, quality of life improvements as a result of increased flexible working, and technological growth in spaces including healthcare and education. The point about misinformation really hit home for me: "Many respondents said their deepest worry is over the seemingly unstoppable manipulation of public perception, emotion and action via online disinformation – lies and hate speech deliberately weaponized in order to propagate destructive biases and fears. They worry about significant damage to social stability and cohesion and the reduced likelihood of rational deliberation and evidence-based policymaking." There is a long appendix of each expert's takes, and they are very thought-provoking.

title: Your first attempt at making anything accessible will be awful
author: Sheri Byrne-Haber
summary: Byrne-Haber explains that making websites accessible is very difficult, but that that shouldn't be an excuse to avoid doing it. I particularly like point 3: "Even people with disabilities can't represent the needs of everyone with any disability", and the takeaway: "98% of websites are completely inaccessible. You couldn't possibly do any worse than they are. The starting point is giving a damn." Something is better than nothing.

title: The Displays: On Anti-Racist Study and Institutional Enclosure
author: David James Hudson
summary: Hudson writes about the performative nature of companies, government institutions, and other organizations in beginning anti-racist initiatives in response to the murder of George Floyd, and how they ignore their own deeply embedded structural racism. "It is hard to sustain interest when the frameworks for doing so center around shock and spectacle, when the institutional terms for doing so offer relief of such shocks through the efficiency of individual reform, when doing such a something is seen as better than doing nothing, is celebrated prominently, its outer limits those of containment rather than mere capacity."

title: Ignoring The History Of Anti-Asian Racism Is Another Form Of Violence
author: Connie Wun
summary: Asian–American history, including the wars that brought many Asian Americans to the US, is not taught or even acknowledged adequately. "As Dr. Mimi Kim, who works on community accountability and transformative justice, once said about the Korean War and its impacts: 'The violence is also in the forgetting.'" There is a myth that Asian Americans are unaffected by white supremacy, which is very much not the case.

title: The George Floyd Act wouldn't have saved George Floyd's life. That says it all
author: Derecka Purnell
summary: The George Floyd Act, which bans police from using chokeholds, would not have saved George Floyd, who did not die from the use of a chokehold. "[Police] can show up and attempt to stop the crime, but they can't stop the underlying conditions that give rise to it: class exploitation and poverty. Floyd appeared to need cash, not the police." The author is also critical of Democrats for taking performative actions without championing meaningful changes.

relatedReading.title: George Floyd Justice in Policing Act

title: Steve Martinez Jailed Again After Refusing To Testify Before A Federal Grand Jury
author: Ryan Fatica
summary: Water protector Steve Martinez is back in custody and faces up to 18 months incarceration for refusing to testify in a grand jury investigation related to the DAPL project and resistance to it. He was previously incarcerated for almost three weeks. "Federal grand juries have long been used as a way of punishing activists and gaining information that law enforcement can use to charge those participating in social movements with crimes."

title: Covid Vaccine Websites Violate Disability Laws, Create Inequity for the Blind
author: Lauren Weber and Hannah Recht
summary: Nearly all vaccine websites across the country do not meet standards required by disability rights laws, and have prevented some blind and visually impaired people from signing up online for vaccination appointments. Blind people are at a higher risk for COVID-19 because they are often unable to distance from people, due to needing assistance with things like grocery shopping.

title: How to be an Active Bystander for Academic Ableism
author: Veronica Lewis
summary: Discusses some examples of academic ableism, and describes what helpful actions bystanders can take to support the victim of such an event.

title: Why Being Black Feels So Overwhelming Right Now
author: Gabriella Effie Forson
summary: Forson writes about the challenges of going about life as though it were "business as usual" in the summer of 2020, with a powerful analogy. She also describes the dissonance of seeing white people posting online as though things were normal, and lists some actions people can take. "Don't shy away because you think it doesn't concern you. If you love a black person or believe in equality this concerns you."

title: Letter and symbol misrecognition in highly legible typefaces for general, children, dyslexic, visually impaired and ageing readers
author: Thomas Bohm
summary: Review of research on characters that are easily confused with other characters, and what typeface changes (for example, serifs) have been shown to increase peoples' ability to distinguish them. Also discusses the existence of "infant characters", a term I'd never heard: "Infant characters, a, g, l, q, y, I, J, 1, 4, 7, 9, are characters specifically designed for people around 6 years old." Goes into some detail about how different visual impairments cause different effects (for example, tunnel vision vs. blurry patches vs. poorer vision at the center of one's field of view). Some of the recommendations in the article were surprising to me: "Sans serif or bracketed serif was preferred over serif. It appears that a slight degree of serif which accentuates the characters ends without distracting from the simple form actually increased legibility."

title: Hidden Curriculum
summary: There are lessons and perspectives that students learn in schools (at all levels) that are unofficial and often unacknowledged, and sometimes mirror or contradict a school's stated values. These lessons shape students' perspectives and learnings in different ways, both positive and negative.

title: The Pinterest Paradox: Cupcakes and Toxicity
author: Francoise Brougher
summary: Francoise Brougher's story of the toxic culture at Pinterest, and some really actionable suggestions on how to be a company that walks the walk when it comes to gender diversity. She later won a large lawsuit against Pinterest for gender discrimination.
